policies.name: Supply Chain Risk Management Policy
policies.description: Organizational policy governing supply chain risk management practices, roles, and responsibilities
policies.rationale: NIST 03.17.01 requires 'develop a plan for managing supply chain risks' which necessitates high-level policy guidance on SCRM approach and governance

policies.name: Information Security Policy
policies.description: Policy covering protection of sensitive organizational documents and plans
policies.rationale: Control requirement (c) mandates 'protect the supply chain risk management plan from unauthorized disclosure'

procedures.name: Supply Chain Risk Assessment Procedure
procedures.description: Step-by-step process for identifying and assessing supply chain risks across the system development life cycle
procedures.rationale: NIST discussion states 'SCRM activities include identifying and assessing risks' requiring documented methodology

procedures.name: SCRM Plan Development and Maintenance Procedure
procedures.description: Process for creating, reviewing, updating, and maintaining the Supply Chain Risk Management Plan
procedures.rationale: Control requires developing and periodically updating the SCRM plan, necessitating a documented process

procedures.name: SCRM Plan Access Control Procedure
procedures.description: Process for controlling access to the SCRM plan and protecting it from unauthorized disclosure
procedures.rationale: Control requirement (c) requires protection mechanisms for the plan

executionEvidence.name: Supply Chain Risk Management Plan
executionEvidence.description: Comprehensive plan documenting: supply chain elements, identified risks, risk response actions, SCRM roles/responsibilities, monitoring approach, lifecycle coverage (research/development/design/manufacturing/acquisition/delivery/integration/operations/maintenance/disposal), implementation constraints, policy implementation details
executionEvidence.rationale: Core deliverable required by control (a); NIST states plan addresses 'management, implementation, and monitoring of SCRM requirements across the system development life cycle'

executionEvidence.name: SCRM Plan Review and Update Records
executionEvidence.description: Documentation showing: review date, reviewer names/roles, changes made, rationale for updates, approval signatures, next review date
executionEvidence.rationale: Control requirement (b) mandates periodic review and update of the SCRM plan

executionEvidence.name: Supply Chain Risk Assessment Reports
executionEvidence.description: Reports documenting: identified supply chain risks, risk severity/likelihood ratings, affected systems/components, threat actors considered (counterfeits, tampering, malicious code insertion, poor development practices), risk response determinations, residual risk levels
executionEvidence.frequency: Annually or when significant supply chain changes occur
executionEvidence.rationale: NIST discussion states 'SCRM activities include identifying and assessing risks, determining appropriate risk response actions'

executionEvidence.name: SCRM Plan Access Control Logs
executionEvidence.description: Audit logs showing: user accessing the plan, date/time of access, access granted/denied, document version accessed
executionEvidence.rationale: Control requirement (c) requires protection from unauthorized disclosure, necessitating access monitoring

executionEvidence.name: SCRM Performance Monitoring Reports
executionEvidence.description: Reports showing: SCRM plan implementation status, metrics on supply chain security, effectiveness of risk response actions, incidents/issues encountered, corrective actions taken
executionEvidence.rationale: NIST discussion states SCRM activities include 'monitoring performance against the plans'

operationalActivities: Identify supply chain elements across entire system lifecycle (R&D through disposal)
Conduct supply chain risk assessments
Determine appropriate risk response actions for identified threats
Develop and maintain comprehensive SCRM plan
Review and update SCRM plan per defined frequency
Implement access controls to protect SCRM plan from unauthorized disclosure
Monitor SCRM plan implementation and effectiveness
Build trust relationships with supply chain partners
Communicate supply chain risks with internal and external stakeholders

policies.name: Supply Chain Risk Management Policy
policies.description: High-level policy governing supply chain security requirements and practices
policies.rationale: NIST 03.17.02 requires 'develop and implement acquisition strategies' to protect supply chain, necessitating policy-level guidance

policies.name: Procurement Security Policy
policies.description: Policy establishing security requirements for procurement and vendor management
policies.rationale: Control requires 'contract tools and procurement methods' requiring policy framework for secure acquisition

procedures.name: Secure Acquisition Procedure
procedures.description: Step-by-step process for implementing secure procurement methods including blind purchases, tamper-evident packaging, trusted distribution, and obscuring end use
procedures.rationale: NIST discussion lists 'many useful tools and techniques' requiring documented implementation procedures

procedures.name: Supplier Evaluation and Vetting Procedure
procedures.description: Process for assessing supplier trustworthiness, security practices, and transparency before approval
procedures.rationale: NIST discussion states organizations 'restrict purchases from untrustworthy suppliers' requiring evaluation methodology

procedures.name: Contract Security Requirements Procedure
procedures.description: Process for incorporating security requirements into contracts, including language prohibiting tainted/counterfeit components
procedures.rationale: NIST discussion emphasizes 'contract language that addresses the prohibition of tainted or counterfeit components'

procedures.name: Supply Chain Training Procedure
procedures.description: Process for delivering training programs on supply chain risks and mitigation strategies to relevant personnel
procedures.rationale: NIST discussion states organizations 'consider providing training, education, and awareness programs for personnel regarding supply chain risks'

executionEvidence.name: Acquisition Strategy Documents
executionEvidence.description: Documented strategies showing: security objectives for acquisitions, risk mitigation approaches, tool/technique selection rationale, alignment with supply chain risk assessment results, protection methods against unauthorized production/theft/tampering/counterfeits
executionEvidence.frequency: Updated annually or when acquisition approach changes
executionEvidence.rationale: Control requires developing 'acquisition strategies' informed by 'results from a supply chain risk assessment'

executionEvidence.name: Secure Procurement Contract Templates
executionEvidence.description: Contract templates incorporating: security requirements for suppliers, prohibition of counterfeit components, transparency requirements, supplier safeguard obligations, documentation protection requirements, remediation provisions
executionEvidence.rationale: NIST discussion states 'contract language that addresses the prohibition of tainted or counterfeit components' and 'Contracts may specify documentation protection requirements'

executionEvidence.name: Supplier Risk Assessment Reports
executionEvidence.description: Assessment reports showing: supplier security practices evaluated, transparency of processes, development practice maturity, trustworthiness determination, approval/rejection decision with rationale
executionEvidence.frequency: Per new supplier or annually for existing suppliers
executionEvidence.rationale: Control requires methods to 'identify, protect against, and mitigate supply chain risks' necessitating supplier evaluation

executionEvidence.name: Supply Chain Training Records
executionEvidence.description: Training certificates and attendance records showing: personnel trained, training completion dates, topics covered (supply chain risks, mitigation strategies, when to employ countermeasures), comprehension assessment results
executionEvidence.frequency: Annually for all personnel involved in procurement/acquisition
executionEvidence.rationale: NIST discussion states organizations provide 'training, education, and awareness programs for personnel regarding supply chain risks, available mitigation strategies'

executionEvidence.name: Contract Security Review Records
executionEvidence.description: Documentation showing: contracts reviewed for security requirements, security provisions verified, deficiencies identified and corrected, approval signatures, review date
executionEvidence.rationale: Control requires implementing 'contract tools' with security provisions necessitating verification of inclusion

executionEvidence.name: Approved Supplier List
executionEvidence.description: List of vetted suppliers showing: supplier name, security capabilities, evaluation date, approval status, restrictions/conditions, re-evaluation schedule
executionEvidence.frequency: Updated quarterly or as suppliers are evaluated
executionEvidence.rationale: NIST discussion states organizations 'restrict purchases from untrustworthy suppliers' requiring maintained list

executionEvidence.name: Secure Procurement Implementation Records
executionEvidence.description: Records showing: use of blind purchases, tamper-evident packaging verification, trusted distribution channels used, end-use obscuring methods applied, per acquisition
executionEvidence.rationale: Control requires implementing 'procurement methods' and NIST lists specific techniques that should be documented when used

operationalActivities: Develop acquisition strategies aligned with supply chain risk assessments
Create and maintain secure contract templates with security requirements
Evaluate and vet suppliers for security practices and trustworthiness
Incorporate security language into procurement contracts
Train personnel on supply chain risks and mitigation strategies
Review contracts for adequate security provisions before execution
Maintain approved supplier list and restrict purchases to vetted suppliers
Implement secure procurement techniques (blind purchases, tamper-evident packaging, trusted distribution)
Provide incentives for suppliers to implement safeguards
Promote transparency in supplier processes and security practices
Review and protect development plans and documentation per security requirements

policies.name: Supply Chain Risk Management Policy
policies.description: Organizational policy establishing supply chain security requirements and governance
policies.rationale: NIST 03.17.03 requires 'enforce security requirements to protect against supply chain risks' necessitating policy-level requirements definition

policies.name: Supplier Security Requirements Policy
policies.description: Policy defining mandatory security requirements for all supply chain elements and suppliers
policies.rationale: Control requirement (b) mandates enforcing 'organization-defined security requirements' requiring formal policy

procedures.name: Supply Chain Weakness Identification Procedure
procedures.description: Step-by-step process for identifying weaknesses and deficiencies in supply chain elements (organizations, entities, tools) and processes (development, shipping, handling, personnel security, configuration management)
procedures.rationale: Control requirement (a) mandates 'establish a process for identifying and addressing weaknesses or deficiencies'

procedures.name: Supply Chain Remediation Procedure
procedures.description: Process for addressing identified supply chain weaknesses, including prioritization, corrective actions, timelines, and verification
procedures.rationale: Control requirement (a) requires 'addressing weaknesses or deficiencies' necessitating remediation methodology

procedures.name: Supplier Security Requirements Procedure
procedures.description: Process for defining, communicating, and enforcing security requirements with suppliers and external service providers
procedures.rationale: Control requirement (b) requires enforcing security requirements to protect against supply chain risks

procedures.name: Supply Chain Element Verification Procedure
procedures.description: Process for verifying authenticity and integrity of supply chain elements including provenance tracking and configuration management
procedures.rationale: NIST discussion emphasizes 'configuration management tools, techniques, and measures to maintain provenance'

executionEvidence.name: Supply Chain Security Requirements Document
executionEvidence.description: Comprehensive requirements document defining: security requirements for hardware/software/firmware development, shipping/handling requirements, physical security requirements, personnel security requirements, configuration management requirements, provenance tracking requirements, disposal requirements, compliance verification methods
executionEvidence.rationale: Control requirement (b) mandates defining and enforcing 'organization-defined security requirements' for supply chain protection

executionEvidence.name: Supply Chain Weakness Assessment Reports
executionEvidence.description: Assessment reports documenting: supply chain elements reviewed, processes evaluated, weaknesses/deficiencies identified, vulnerability severity ratings, potential adversary exploitation vectors, impact on mission/business functions, prioritization for remediation
executionEvidence.frequency: Quarterly or when significant supply chain changes occur
executionEvidence.rationale: Control requirement (a) requires process for identifying weaknesses; NIST states 'weaknesses represent potential vulnerabilities that can be exploited by adversaries'

executionEvidence.name: Supply Chain Remediation Plans and Records
executionEvidence.description: Plans showing: identified weakness, root cause, corrective action plan, responsible parties, implementation timeline, completion status, verification method, residual risk assessment
executionEvidence.rationale: Control requirement (a) requires 'addressing weaknesses or deficiencies' necessitating remediation tracking

executionEvidence.name: Supplier Compliance Audit Reports
executionEvidence.description: Audit reports showing: supplier evaluated, security requirements assessed, compliance verification results, non-compliance items identified, corrective action requirements, follow-up schedule
executionEvidence.frequency: Annually per supplier or service provider
executionEvidence.rationale: Control requirement (b) requires enforcing security requirements, necessitating verification of supplier compliance

executionEvidence.name: Supply Chain Process Documentation
executionEvidence.description: Documented processes for each supply chain element covering: hardware/software/firmware development processes, shipping/handling procedures, physical security programs, personnel security programs, configuration management approach, provenance maintenance, acquisition/maintenance/disposal procedures
executionEvidence.frequency: Reviewed annually or when processes change
executionEvidence.rationale: NIST discussion defines 'supply chain processes' requiring documentation of all relevant procedures

executionEvidence.name: Configuration Management and Provenance Records
executionEvidence.description: Records showing: component tracking from acquisition through disposal, configuration baselines, changes tracked, authenticity verification, chain of custody documentation, counterfeit detection methods applied
executionEvidence.frequency: Ongoing for all supply chain components
executionEvidence.rationale: NIST discussion emphasizes 'configuration management tools, techniques, and measures to maintain provenance' as key supply chain process

executionEvidence.name: Supply Chain Element Inventory
executionEvidence.description: Inventory of all supply chain elements showing: organizations/entities/tools used, their role in supply chain (R&D, design, manufacturing, acquisition, delivery, integration, operations, maintenance, disposal), security assessment status, compliance verification date
executionEvidence.frequency: Updated monthly or as supply chain changes
executionEvidence.rationale: NIST discussion defines 'supply chain elements include organizations, entities, or tools' requiring comprehensive inventory

operationalActivities: Identify and document all supply chain elements (organizations, entities, tools)
Document supply chain processes for hardware, software, firmware development
Define security requirements for all supply chain elements and suppliers
Conduct regular assessments to identify supply chain weaknesses and deficiencies
Address identified weaknesses through remediation plans
Enforce security requirements with suppliers and service providers
Verify supplier compliance with defined security requirements through audits
Implement configuration management to maintain component provenance
Track supply chain components from acquisition through disposal
Monitor supply chain for potential adversary exploitation vectors
Maintain inventory of all supply chain elements and their security status
Coordinate physical security, personnel security, and technical security across supply chain
